awd_titl_txt: High Precision Measurements of Beta Decay Using Stored Ultracold Neutrons and Cold Neutron Beams
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports high precision measurements of neutron beta decay, a process in which a neutron decays, because of the weak nuclear force (or weak interaction), into a proton, an electron and an anti-neutrino.  The weak nuclear force is important, in that it powers our sun and helps determine the abundance of elements in the universe.  Neutron decay is also important because it involves only a single nucleon, making possible very precise predictions from the "standard model" of particle physics without the complications due to the presence of other nucleons.  With very accurate measurements of neutron decay, we can perform a kind of particle physics "forensics", looking for discrepancies in our standard model which can indicate the presence of new forces, but without using high energy particle beams such as those at the Large Hadron Collider at CERN.  This research is a part of the "precision frontier" for physics, and defines the cutting edge of our knowledge of the weak nuclear force and possible new interactions.  The PI and his group contribute to a new measurement of the neutron's lifetime (UCNtau) and an angular correlation measurement (Nab).  The lifetime and angular correlations measurements probe different aspects of the weak interaction, and if successful, will sharpen our knowledge of critical components of the weak interaction and contribute to strong limits on extensions the standard model, at or above those which are being established at CERN.   An important aspect of the project is the training of students and post-docs. This training comes in part because of the specific nature of the research projects, which utilize nuclear physics analysis and technology (which also has real-world applications in energy generation and medical imaging, for example) and in part from the many opportunities students working in the program have to perform research at national laboratories and nuclear facilities.  

One of the experiments supported by the award, Nab, will use an unpolarized beam of cold neutrons at the Spallation Neutron Source from the Oak Ridge National Laboratory to measure the angular correlation between the decay electron and the anti-neutrino (called the electron-anti-neutrino correlation), with the goal of over an order of magnitude improvement in the precision of this parameter.  The other, UCNtau, is situated at the ultracold neutron (UCN) source at Los Alamos National Laboratory (LANL), and targets precision levels below 0.3 seconds during the current funding period. The impact of these programs being successful are: (1) knowledge of the axial form factor at the level required to determine the CKM matrix element Vud at the same level as the current theoretical uncertainty for the electro-weak radiative corrections, (2) knowledge of the lifetime at a level such that it will limit tests of our models for the cosmological He-4 abundance for some time, and (3) limits on tensor couplings at or above the level expected from CERN.  Motivation for these measurements has been amplified over the last year by theoretical progress on the electroweak radiative corrections and lattice calculations of the axial coupling constant, with both opening new, higher precision probes for new physics. For each of these experiments, this group brings its experience in beta decay measurements to bear on key sources of systematic error by developing instrumentation and analysis required by the experiments.  For Nab, for example, the group is analyzing the effects of incomplete collection of the energy of decay electrons and the calibration procedures, a critical component of the systematic error budget for this experiment.  UCNtau is designed to store UCNs in a magneto-gravitational trap, where the UCNs do not contact with the trap walls.  The top of the trap is open, permitting detectors to be lowered into the trap to measure UCN populations and determine the lifetime.  The group will continue to develop UCN detectors for this purpose and focus additional effort on understanding systematic errors due to UCNs with high enough energies to slowly escape the trap and shift the measured value of the lifetime.  These tasks are essential and ongoing parts of the planned experiments, with completed measurements and analysis incorporated into publications during the proposal period.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of this project was to provide high precision measurements of the beta decay of free neutrons, a process caused by the weak nuclear force.  In neutron decay, the neutron transforms into a proton, emitting an electron and an antineutrino.  The weak force helps power the sun, determine elemental abundances during the big bang, and governs the radioactive decay of many isotopes in our environment.  Unlike typical nuclear decays where the neutron is bound inside a nucleus, the decay of an individual, free neutron is not complicated by the presence of neighboring nucleons. This simplifies  the theoretical description of the decay process, ensuring the most reliable predictions and making free neutron decay an ideal target for high precision measurements.

In fact, beta decay measurements already provide us with our most accurate information on the weak nuclear force, establishing one of the foundations for the particle physics “Standard Model,” where the weak force is characterized by a vector and axial-vector coupling constant (gV and gA respectively). The goal of our experimental program was to push the frontier of the precision and reliability of our knowledge of these coupling constants.  These measurements augment our understanding of the Standard Model and permit us to search for new physics by looking for discrepancies between what we expect from the Standard Model and what we determine from experiments.   Using measurements of the neutron beta decay lifetime along with measurements of the angular correlation of the decay products, one can probe in this way for new physics at the same energy scales as in collider experiments at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN. 

The supported experimental program provided improved measurements of the neutron lifetime (with the UCNtau collaboration) and angular correlation measurements of the electron asymmetry (iwth the UCNA collaboration). We also contributed to the development of a next generation experiment that will measure both an angular correlation and an electron spectrum (with the Nab collaboration).  Both UCNA and UCNtau use ultracold neutrons (UCNs, velocities <10 m/s) to measure neutron decay and Nab uses cold neutrons (~800 m/s).  UCNA was the first experiment to use UCN to measure an angular correlation in beta decay, and was brought to conclusion during this project period, where the correlation between the emitted electron and the neutron spin (the “beta asymmetry”) was measured to be -0.12054(76). This resulted in an axial coupling constant value of gA =-1.2772(20) when taken together with previous UCNA results, and provided the most precise cross-check to date of more traditional cold neutron measurements.

The UCNtau experiment uses magnetically trapped, polarized UCN in a large (bathtub size) bowl-shaped array of magnets.  UCN are loaded into the trap, cleaned to remove neutrons that can escape from the trap, then the remaining UCN are stored for either a short (50 s) or long (1550 s) time. The surviving neutrons were counted and used to determine the lifetime.  This approach constitutes a breakthrough for the field, in that the systematic corrections are, for the first time, assessed below the current level of statistical uncertainty, paving the way for precision levels below 0.3 s and more reliable values for the neutron coupling constants.  The mean neutron lifetime determined from this measurement was 877.7(8) seconds.

The Nab experiment will utilize an optimized magnetic spectrometer to measure the angular correlation between the emitted neutrino and the recoiling proton. Nab is sited at the Spallation Neutron Source at Oak Ridge National Laboratory. Our group was responsible for characterizing aspects of detector response.  Because Nab has a very different systematic error budget than UCNA or the other cold neutron beam experiments that are planned, it can make crucial contributions to the field.

The improved measurements reported by UCNA and UCNtau have helped establish the most precise parameters for the charged weak current for nucleons, and contribute directly to constraints for new physics relevant for particle physics. These experiments have broader impact for particle physics and cosmology, with constraints on neutron decay to dark particles produced by UCNA and UCNtau as well.

These experiments also provided in-depth training for students and post-docs to enter academia, national laboratory positions, and industry.  As a part of our commitment to student training, the last two years of this project focused on training a graduate student during a transition period between an Engineering and Physics PhD program and integrating that student into our neutron research program.  This process is now nearing a successful end, with the student ready to contribute to our research efforts full-time in 2025.   Identifying talented students and working to match their needs as they ready for research is one way we support the growing community of neutron scientists, in fundamental physics, in the neutron scattering community, and in other aspects of neutron production and energy generation.
